0.title: the warmest three/two
paragraphs: The Warmest 3/2mm of the season was the Rip Curl Heat Seeker. Wetsuits competing for the title were:

1.title: the comfort stretch award four/three
paragraphs: The wetsuit for those who like their yoga in silk pants is the O’Neill Hyperfreak Comp. The Wetsuits entered into the Stretchiest and Comfiest 4/3mm category were:

2.title: champagne and caviar
paragraphs: The best lux suits over $450

3.title: the budget warrior (under $300)
paragraphs: The finest wetsuit for the frugal is the O’Neill Hyperfreak Comp

4.title: the fastest drying
paragraphs: All suits entered the fastest drying category, but after one use of the Rip Curl Heat Seeker featuring their Flashbomb lining, it was clear, no suit dries as fast as a Rip Curl.

5.title: feeling lovely (most stylish)
paragraphs: Like the fastest drying, every suit was entered into the best looking category. After careful analysis, the FERAL 4/3mm backzip was unanimously voted the sexiest wetsuit on the market.
Just like the 90’s, backzips are back!

0.title: O'Neill
paragraphs: During our test, O'Neill's suits were not only the easiest on and off but the most flexible and comfortable. So, the fact that their Hyperfreak Comp was nominated and won both the Stretch and Comfort and the Best Wetsuit for Under $300USD was unsurprising.

For O’Neill, it all comes down to two words: Techno Butter. The Techno Butter Technology is three phases in the making and has hit its pinnacle. Both wetsuits they sent us to test, the Hyperfreak Comp $299USD and the Psychofreak $530USD are super-freaky-cozy.

1.title: Vissla
paragraphs: For (one of) the most affordable wetsuit manufacturers on the market, Vissla is your go. Their 7 Seas suit doesn’t exceed $200USD and their premium line, The North Seas, falls just under $300USD.
Vissla makes a no-frills wetsuit, if you own one, you know its functionality is nothing to get upset over. You get more than you pay for.

Plus, if we are going on sheer aesthetics, Vissla’s are hawt. The 7 Seas and the North Seas come with a variety of understated flair. They also make a version with no logos at all for those who prefer to stray from brand affiliation and appreciate a company that honors that individual.
The Vissla’s look good, feel fine, and as Noah noted in our short documentary about the best wetsuits of 2018, they “even taste good.”

2.title: FERAL
paragraphs: FERAL Wetsuits are likely a brand you’re unfamiliar with. If so, you should get acquainted. Their 4/3mm Backzip was voted by all of our wetsuit samplers to be the sexiest on the market.

All FERAL’s are made from Yamamoto Neoprene (which after a week testing suits, it became clear, there simply is no neoprene on the market as lightweight, comfortable and functional as Yamamoto Japanese Neoprene), but unlike most companies pushing the Yama, FERAL keeps their price point low.
Their 4/3mm runs for $385USD and their 3/2mm goes for $375USD (all suits come in chest zip or backzip, so choose according to your kink).
FERAL is 100 percent Stab Recommended and was a favorite during our wetsuit test.

3.title: Billabong
paragraphs: The kind folks from Billabong delivered three suits to Stab HQ for our wetsuit test: One Furnace Carbon Ultra 3/2mm, a Furnace Revolution 4/3mm that runs just over $200USD and the most expensive suit from their collection, the Furnace Carbon Ultra Chestzip 4/3mm ($410USD).

The one thing we dug about the Billabong suits, is their price point is low. Their budget suit, the Billabong Furnace Revolution runs $209USD. Upon first wear, the wetsuit was, admittedly, a little scratchy. However, once you break it in, it loosens up. For a 4/3 costing just under $210USD, the Furnace Revolution, is a fine suit for any penny pincher.

4.title: Quiksilver
paragraphs: Quik sent us one suit for our test, convinced it would lead the way in the warmest 3/2mm category.
It did not.
However, their suit did get third. But, it's worth noting that the first place finisher, the Rip Curl Heat Seeker, runs $500USD, while Quik’s Highline Plus 3/2mm costs just $314USD.
The Highline Plus fared warm in the cold water of Ocean Beach, San Francisco. It’s the right suit for anyone who wouldn’t dare spend over $400USD on a neoprene kit.

5.title: Xcel
paragraphs: We applaud Xcel for being the most consistently high-quality suit on the market.

For our test, Xcel sent us three pieces of rubber to sample. And, after our wetsuiteers, being Noah Wegrich, Blair Conklin and Jesse Guglielmana, gave each one a run, we came to the conclusion, that Xcel is, in fact, a damn fine purveyor of comfort, flex and warmth.

Here we highlight the Comp X ($365USD), The Drylock X 3/2 ($485USD), and, the Drylock X 4/3 ($500USD). The Comp X, won the SIMA award in 2017 for the best suit of the year, and in “You’ve Got Winter” won over our field tester’s hearts. Although the Comp X didn’t take gold in comfort and stretch, it did come in second, with Noah “Waggy” Wegrich giving it his first pick.
The Comp X also came in second in the good looks department.
Xcel’s crème de la crème suits, the Drylock Xs will run you near $500USD, they’re watertight-ish, cozy and well worth the expense.

6.title: Rip Curl
paragraphs: In the only fashion they know, Rip Curl took two of our categories in “You’ve Got Winter.” During our field test, we pulled the Rip Curl Heat Seeker 3/2mm out of its box, saw the Tron patches, or, er, Thermo Shield up the arms and thought, “Ooo, Techy.”
After giving it a go in the cold waters of San Francisco, it was unanimously chosen the warmest 3/2mm any of us had ever worn.
Such warmth, however, comes at a price tag of $500USD.
The Heat Seeker is equipped with their Flashbomb technology, and thus won the fastest drying wetsuit in the event (dry as the desert in 30 minutes!).
Rip Curl also sent us their E-Bomb Zipper Free 4/3mm. This will run you just under $300USD ($299). If you’re loyal to the Curl, or are looking to try something new, the E-Bomb won’t lead you astray.

7.title: Hurley
paragraphs: As we all tried and tested the Hurley Elite Advantage 3mm, we raved about its comfort, flex and warmth (three qualities that make a good suit). It’s easily the best wetsuit Hurley’s made, and it really should be with the price tag of $750USD.

If you’re a high-performance doyen who has owned a white, pink or red wetsuit at any point in your life, the white stripes down the leg might be your first step into black – while still wearing something that will separate you from the crowd with every air rev you (obviously) stick.
If you’ve got big pockets and love a little tech and flair, go on and shop the Hurley Advantage Elite 3mm.

8.title: 7till8
paragraphs: Here’s another neoprene specialist that likely sits outside your radar. The Los Angeles custom wetsuit manufacturer, 7till8, took the highest reward in our Champagne and Caviar category (the finest wetsuit for over $450USD).
7till8 sent us a 4/3mm which costs the same as their 3/2mm, 3mm, 5/4/3mm, etc: $580USD.

All of 7till8’s wetsuits are made from Yamamoto Japanese Neoprene, and every suit they make is a custom order. It’s this extra care that gave 7till8 the nod for the best Luxury suit from Blair Conklin, Noah Wegrich, Jesse Guglielmana and our senior editor, Morgan Williamson.

9.title: Volcom
paragraphs: The Stone has entered the wetsuit game with diamonds blazing. They’ve teamed up with FERAL to produce their first wetsuit available to the every-person called the Deadly Stone. It’s a 3/2mm. It’s a backzip. It’s made from Yamamoto Neoprene.

It’s cozier than a campfire. And, if you’ve always dreamt of walking into the water with youth against establishment branded across your slick skin, go on and shop Volcom’s first step into the every(wo)man’s wetsuit realm.
